item.name: 4 First Games
item.comment: Wow, I grew up with this game in the early 80's. I haven't thought about it in years. Those crazy dogs and their sausage-stealing antics! This was my introduction to board games!

item.name: 5-Minute Dungeon
item.comment: Got the kickstarter edition

item.name: 5-Minute Marvel
item.comment: Got this for Father's Day 2019

item.name: 5-Minute Mystery
item.comment: Kickstarted it. We've had a lot of fun playing this with the kids because there's plenty to do. We've ever gone past the green scenarios though!

item.name: 7 Wonders
item.comment: Such a great game, with several qualities that make it a top choice to come off the shelf. It supports up to seven players - frequently a necessity. Everyone plays simultaneously - awesome, we don't have to wait a half hour for each turn. And it's just cards, so we don't have to spend a half hour setting up a board and lots of tokens and whatnot. It's ease of setup, speed of play, and support of many people make it the best choice a lot of the time.

item.name: The 7th Continent
item.comment: Was really intrigued by the concept, but it's more finicky than I had imagined. I'm not actually all that interested in the survival challenge of the game, more in the exploration. I think I will keep coming back to it and exploring more parts of the island but I am not in love with the experience. I'm definitely interested in some variants that make it lighter and easier to just explore the story.

item.name: Above and Below
item.comment: Bought a used copy off the Geek market. A combines a light-weight worker placement / building / resource collection game (which would not be that interesting on its own) with a charming adventure system that is like a choose-your-own adventure / super-light-weight RPG. I wouldn't call this a game for hard-core gamers since there is a fair amount of luck and randomness but I have really enjoyed it with younger player and people who are more into RPG's.

item.name: Acquire
item.comment: My wife grew up with this game so I got the newest reprint. We've played it once. I wasn't all that taken with it, and I haven't felt like putting in the time to get better at it.

item.name: The Adventurers: The Pyramid of Horus
item.comment: I really like this game. I like the different options that are all open to you, and the wounds mechanic is a huge improvement on the first game. This game is ALWAYS tense at the end, which I like. Some have ended in mass destruction, sometimes we are all cowards and run out quickly, and every once in a while someone manages to dance around the stones and escape with a massive load of treasure.

item.name: The Adventurers: The Temple of Chac
item.comment: I like this game conceptually more than I like actually playing it. I appreciate that it was the first Adventurers game but I like the second one better. This one feels mostly the same whenever I play it, and it feels like there are fewer tense decisions. You are either grabbing tons of treasure or dying a grisly and sudden death.

item.name: Age of Civilization
item.comment: Got it on clearance sale from Amazon. Looks really neat, I love the art on the wonder cards. The small package and components are really nice. The actual game has some good ideas but overall it has _too many_ ideas and is more fiddly and less intuitive than it should be. It's pretty close - I could see a streamlined revision being quite fun.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment: I really appreciate the depth of the design of this game, and the extent to which reality is modeled. It still takes a long time to set up and play, but I always enjoy it.

item.name: The aMAZEing Labyrinth
item.comment: Such a good game! Simple rules are easy to learn, but each turn requires some actual thought, especially when the maze is complicated. Like Carcasonne light, but lighting quick to set up and play. My favorite end-of-the-night / had-a-few-drinks game!

item.name: Andor: The Family Fantasy Game
item.comment: Got it for the kids for their 8th birthday. It's quite a good design with lots of choices and plenty of flexibility for the players. I like the action mechanics with the sun tokens to track them, and the ability to do more if you want to. We've had success getting the kids to play it, if not always lasting through a whole game. But they certainly get what's going on and are able to fully participate.

item.name: Android: Netrunner
item.comment: I'll admit that I don't fully get it. I want to, and I'd like to have a player base to enjoy the game with. Unfortunately I don't.

item.name: Ascension: Deckbuilding Game
item.comment: Initially learned the Dreamscape version, but got hooked anyway. We have been enjoying the base game (3rd ed.) plus Return of the Fallen regularly for a while now. I much prefer to teach this deck-building game to a new player rather than Dominion or Thunderstone. I appreciate that the turn structure is super minimal. And I also like that there is very little setup. Shuffle the big pile and go! I think that its minimal setup will help it outlast Thunderstone and even Dominion in my book.

item.name: Axis & Allies 1941
item.comment: Picked it up at WalMart. Hoping to play it some more. Not super impressed by the combat mechanics, but they're better than Risk...

item.name: Azul
item.comment: Picked it up at Target. Beautiful deign and pretty interesting mechanically. The drafting has some nuance, and the strategy for placing tiles is interesting too.

item.name: Bandido
item.comment: A fairly cute little puzzle type game that makes you think. Got old fairly quickly though.

item.name: Battleship
item.comment: Tommy got this for Christmas 2019

item.name: Blitzkrieg!: World War Two in 20 Minutes
item.comment: Bought from Game Nerdz

item.name: Blood Bowl (2016 Edition)
item.comment: I got a copy and painted up all the minis which was a lot of fun. I think I would like it more if I played it more.

item.name: Buffy the Vampire Slayer: The Game
Cadwallon: City of Thieves
item.comment: Not overly impressed with this one after an introductory play or two, but I think with the right crowd it could be interesting. I think in my collection it falls into a crack between the mass-appeal games like 7 Wonders and the more niche games like LotR LCG and Chaos in the Old World. So it's not really in the wheelhouse of any of the groups of people I play with.

item.name: Carcassonne Big Box
item.comment: Carcassonne was one of the early games that got me back into board games, especially Euros and strategy games. This Big Box was a natural purchase after we had exhausted the basic game. Actually thought, only Traders and Builders has really stood up for us. The Dragon one is no fun (we don't like the slower, lower scoring game) and the others seem too fiddly. Still a great one to have on the shelf though.

item.name: Chaos in the Old World
item.comment: Excellent game. Gets extra marks because of the awesome design and production. We usually spend more time talking about strategy and re-hashing games than we do playing the actual games. That tells me this game has depth!

item.name: Checkers
item.comment: The kids were quite into this for a while between 6-7. They hadn't really learned any "modern" games yet.

item.name: Citadels
item.comment: Bought this back in 2003 or 4. One of the first "modern" games I played.

item.name: Cleopatra and the Society of Architects
item.comment: Very interesting game, I like the challenge of the corruption and the fun of trying to walk the line between too much and not enough. It's fun to have some indirect player interaction, when jockeying for plaza space or choosing draw piles. And the final reveal of the pyramids is always exciting!

item.name: Codenames: Pictures
item.comment: Awesome crazy twist on the original

item.name: The Crew: The Quest for Planet Nine
Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition)
item.comment: Was somewhat excited about this when I first got into it with my buddies. Seemed like a good dungeon crawl / quest game, what with the continuing campaign and the character progression. We pretty quickly got disillusioned though, when it became obvious that it is more of a tactical miniature game than a dungeon crawler. The actual encounters and the overall campaign were interesting, but the grind and nitty-gritty tactics of winning individual encounters were not what we were looking for. We gave up most of the way through the campaign.

item.name: Dixit
item.comment: Interesting game - I admire the design of it. I usually find myself wishing the game were a little more fun than it turns out to be. Planning on getting some expansions anyway, because there is a good deal of fun here.

item.name: Dominion
item.comment: Played friends' copies for years and finally bought my own copy. I have introduced quite a few new people to this game, mostly non-gamers.

item.name: Dragonwood
item.comment: The kids quite like this one. We had some fun with it even as adults - it's interesting how the different modes of attack are better vs. different monsters. You have to push your luck a little but you don't get punished too hard for failure. I appreciate that they weighted the dice so each additional one is 2.5 average average attack.

item.name: Dune: Imperium
item.comment: Kind of like "Lords of Waterdeep Advanced", plus deckbuilding. It was love at first sight for me. I am a big fan of the Dune books, worker placement games, strategic games, and deckbuilding games. I also love the design, both visual and game. The theme feels well-integrated, there is a good variety of ways to score points, and a good amount of hidden planning and intrigue. Feels like it has a lot of depth without being insanely complicated or brain-burning.

item.name: Dungeon Roll
item.comment: Kickstarted it! Enjoying the solo play quite a bit. Lots of variety thanks to the 17 hero cards.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
Dungeons & Dragons: Temple of Elemental Evil Board Game
item.comment: Adds a little bit to the existing games, but not a ton. Still fun, but the basics are getting a little tired.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: The Legend of Drizzt Board Game
item.comment: Continues the fun, and amps things up a bit more than the previous two games. The heroes are more powerful, the treasures are a little better, the monsters are more interesting, and the quest are slightly more involved.

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons: Wrath of Ashardalon Board Game
item.comment: Has almost taken over weekly game nights that used to involve actual D&D. We've had so many games come down to one die roll or one critical turn. Gets pretty exciting, and pretty hard towards the end of the missions.

item.name: Earth Reborn
item.comment: I really like the design, theme, and production quality of this game. It's super fun.

item.name: Elder Sign
item.comment: I used to play this on the app a long time ago, and Tommy was interested in it. I tried to remember how to play the app and figured it would be easier to do in real life so I ordered the physical version.

item.name: Evolution: The Beginning
item.comment: I enjoy this way more than the full version - I like it very simple and streamlined. Tommy got into it which gave it a bit of life.

item.name: Fight for Olympus
item.comment: I really like this game. It's simple and pretty streamlined but has a lot of interesting choices. I have had fun in all the games so far, wins and losses. I kind of get a "Magic the Gathering" vibe from it, but with many fewer possible interactions and a simpler structure.

item.name: Fireball Island: The Curse of Vul-Kar
item.comment: Got it for Christmas 2018, fittingly exactly 30 years after I got the original one for Christmas. This is a wonderful remake - everything got way better in every way.

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue
item.comment: A nice change of pace from the Pandemic family of cooperative board games. Some familiar concepts but a totally unique theme and set of mechanics. The expansions are hard, but the basic boards are fun for everyone.

item.name: Forbidden Desert
item.comment: We are really enjoying this game. It feels similar enough to Forbidden Island but also different enough to be interesting. I love that the hand-management is gone, and that trading things is free. This is a great game.

item.name: Forbidden Island
item.comment: There is no game I would rather have to teach cooperative games to my friends with. This game is a masterpiece of elegance in that in combines the difficulty of Pandemic but provides a level of simple game-play that is easy to get into. The fact that I can play this game with my adult friends as well as my young nephews says a lot. Forbidden Island provides a ton of depth with just a few rules.

item.name: Forbidden Sky
item.comment: An interesting evolution of the "Forbidden" games. It's different enough to feel unique. We played it some but no one has ever really demanded we play it more.

item.name: Formula D
item.comment: Crazy dice-rolling fun, especially great with around 5 players. My favorite parts are the cheering at good rolls and the screaming at bad rolls. Also the merciless heckling of other players, and the adrenaline of finishing a race with no points left to spend.

item.name: Frog Juice
item.comment: This is just a solid, light card game. I have been in love with this game since I first played in as a teen. The theme is fun, the rules are very basic but have a few extra wrinkles, and the games don't take very long to play. I put a lot of hours into making a computer version just because I like this game so much. It really highlights the basic math game plus slight strategy card game.

item.name: Gears of War: The Board Game
item.comment: Brutal. Just brutal. Especially with four players it is really punishing. But so much damn fun! It really is a high quality game. One of the harder co-op games I played though.

item.name: Gloomhaven: Jaws of the Lion
item.comment: Picked this up to help learn the game. Got an in-person group going. Enjoyed and appreciated the gentle introductory scenarios. I love playing the Hatchet so far.

item.name: Go Go Gelato!
item.comment: This was fun when the kids were little. I think we gave it away. Really simple and fun activity. Loved the colors.

item.name: Guess Who?
item.comment: Ali got it for Christmas 2019

item.name: Hanabi
item.comment: Nice and simple rules, but complex and interesting play. I like this much more for the elegance of its design than I do for the actual solving of the puzzle. But it is good clean fun.

item.name: Hero Realms
item.comment: Seems like an acceptable reskin of Star Realms, which I really like. The card art is good overall, but the graphic design makes the cards hard to read, especially the micro text. The guard champions needing to be un-tapped in order to defend is an interesting wrinkle.

item.name: HeroQuest
item.comment: Provided hours of fun as a kid. Made my brother and cousin play through so many levels. Had endless fun making up new items, character classes, and levels. Made up my own character sheets and map templates on the computer too.

item.name: HeroQuest
item.comment:
Backed it on Haslab. Super cool and excited to introduce my kids!
The production quality is fantastic. The game itself is basically unchanged so it's fine with kids but I think adults might get bored with it.

item.name: The Hobbit: The Defeat of the Evil Dragon Smaug
item.originalname: The Hobbit: The Defeat of Smaug
item.comment: Ordered the 2103 Reiner Knitzia one from Amazon and got this instead!

item.name: Indiana Jones Akator Temple Race Game
item.comment: Bought a cheapo copy off of eBay. Planning to use the tower in some sort of D&D encounter. Might actually play the game some time.

item.name: Infinity Gauntlet: A Love Letter Game
item.comment: Ordered from Game Nerdz. Looking forward to trying it out with the family since we love Love Letter and could maybe use a little variation.

item.name: Jump Drive
item.comment: Played twice with Mel. Got the hang of it fairly quickly and enjoyed it. Definitely feels like playing race, but at a much lower mental level. We both found that thinking ahead didn't help much. And there are far fewer decisions. But I enjoyed the streamlined play and the fast setup. Definitely approachable and teachable. Oh, and I crushed Mel twice. Once with the blue starting hand and once with a crazy Galactic Trend Setters combo.

item.name: Kingdomino
item.comment:
Ali got it for Christmas 2021 (has incorrect rule book).
I like how quick it is to play but how many decisions I get to make. Scoring is always interesting and I enjoy seeing what I was able to accomplish.

item.name: The Legend of Zelda
item.comment: The original co-op game! I remember lots of fun with my Grandmother and my brother trying to get Link all the way to the end. We rarely made it all the way to Gannon because of our short attention spans but I loved this game anyway.

item.name: Loaded Questions
item.comment: Not sure where this came from. Maybe a wedding present :-P

item.name: Loot
item.comment: Fun and light card game. Has slightly weird choices / incentives (i.e. it's usually not clear that playing a merchant ship is actually a good idea). The only real flaw is that it's hard to tell the green pirate ships from the blue ones.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings
item.comment: A Masterpiece

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: Journey to Mordor
item.comment: Bought from Game Nerdz. Nice and tidy little dice roll and write

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
item.comment: I suspected I would be hooked on this game the first time I played it. I was introduced in 2015 by my friend Chrispy. It wasn't necessarily love at first sight, but as I kept thinking about the game in the days following I knew I was going to have to buy it. I enjoy that I can play it solo and do a little deck building (a nice escape into nostalgia for my old MtG days) but I really enjoy playing with one or two friends. The cooperative discussions about how to overcome the challenges of the quests, and how to tweak the decks between plays are my favorite moments. I am glad there are a lot of expansions, because this is a game that I feel like I just want to keep playing. It's telling that the box and the cards have been permanently out on my gaming room table for months on end.

item.name: Lords of Waterdeep
item.comment: Definitely the worker placement game that I want to teach to new gamers. Also my favorite theme. I still like this game quite a bit but it needs just a little bit of help from an expansion.

item.name: Lost Cities
item.comment: My wife and I found this interesting, so it's nice that it's a two-player game. That being said we haven't been itching to get it back out much.

item.name: Love Letter
item.comment:
I want to like this game. I think I really need to find a group that wants to play it. I think I mostly appreciate it, but no one I've played it with has ever wanted to play it again :-(
Update 2022: have been playing this a lot with Ali and she's great at it. I really like it two-player, and it's fun with three or sometimes four as a family.

item.name: Magic Realm Light 30
item.comment: Fun and easy introduction to the Magic Realm rules. I enjoyed playing it solo, and even crafted a more 3D set out of colored felt for the map and various bones minis for the monsters and lairs.

item.name: Mahjong
item.comment: Sort of a hard way to have fun compared to more modern games. Still an interesting challenge and I enjoy picking a category and then narrowing in on a specific hand. A major weakness is when your hand is clearly dead half-way through the game.

item.name: Mille Bornes
item.comment: A childhood classic - played it on the Mac.

item.name: Monopoly Deal Card Game
item.comment: Enough going on and fast enough pace to be pretty entertaining.

item.name: Monopoly: Star Wars Limited Collector's Edition
item.comment: Yes I have actually played this, as an adult. It's Monopoly all right.

item.name: New Frontiers
item.comment: Interesting evolution of Race for the Galaxy. I'm not sure I like the board game stuff more than the original cards, but I do like the tactile elements of the colonists, credit chips, and goods. I enjoy the difference pace this one offers and the always-available developments.

item.name: Nexus Ops
item.comment: Wow, this game is super fun and exciting. Plenty of interesting decisions, and the rules are lightweight and streamlined enough that it doesn't burn your brain. I could play a lot more games of this.

item.name: One Page 40k
item.comment: So great. What a gift to the community. Makes me want to get my armies off the shelf and set up a game! So much simpler and more fun than all the book-keeping and mind-numbing detail of regular 40k. Just dice and fun.

item.name: Onirim
item.comment: I enjoy the solo game quite a bit. Haven't tried it with two yet.

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: THE cooperative game

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment: Overall I really like the new design and updates. Got a board missing the Lagos-Sao Paulo route. New roles are cool.

item.name: Pandemic Legacy: Season 1
item.comment: Excellent adaptation of the original into the legacy format. Really enjoyed playing through it and progressing the story. We had a dramatic finish at the end.

item.name: Pandemic Legacy: Season 2
item.comment: Picked it up in the summer of 2020 after playing through the first season during the actual real-life Pandemic!

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords – Base Set
item.comment: From the Chrispy collection. Played the entire campaign with two friends using a party of Barbarian, Wizard, and Monk.

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth
item.comment: On loan from the Chrispy Collection

item.name: Police Precinct
item.comment: Kickstarted the 2nd edition. It arrived May 27th, 2015!

item.name: Power Grid: The Card Game
item.comment: A definite disappointment- we were hoping for a light and simple Power Grid (like Evolution: the Beginning) but this turned out to be not as fun and just as fiddly if not worse. It really missed the mark.

item.name: Pretty Pretty Princess
item.comment: Tommy and Ali got this for their third birthday.

item.name: Province
item.comment: Kickstarted this. Nice micro-size but there are a lot more rules and fiddly bits than I was expecting. Looking forward to playing this with Mel.

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: My rating for this game definitely suffers because I came to it too late. I had already learned and appreciated many games that derived from it. I still enjoyed the learning and playing of Puerto Rico, but I think I actually liked reading about the strategy more than I enjoyed playing the game to discover it myself. I do like the theme and production.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment: My all time favorite. Maybe the perfect game.

item.name: The Red Dragon Inn
item.comment: Just plain fun. Actually a really well-designed game that is easy to learn and play. Lighthearted, great art, and really funny. Simple enough that non-gamers have a good time playing it, and endless inside jokes for us D&D nerds.

item.name: The Red Dragon Inn 2
item.comment: Nearly as good as the original, not quite the creativity I could have hoped for

item.name: The Red Dragon Inn 4
item.comment: Kickstarted it!

item.name: Res Arcana
item.comment: Was really excited for a new design from Tom and this one is definitely different. Not trying to build all your cards made our heads spin. There's a lot more depth here that I would like to explore. I am not very good at it yet but I want to keep playing to get better.

item.name: Risk: The Lord of the Rings
Robot Turtles
item.comment: On loan from the W. Cravens collection

item.name: Rolling Seas
item.comment:
My cousin is friends with the designer and he sent me a copy.
I hadn't really played a "roll and write" style game before and this was a good introduction. I like rolling for the wind and the adventure. There's a lot of depth here that would be fun to explore more.

item.name: Sagrada
item.comment: Got it for Christmas 2021

item.name: Scoville
item.comment: Kickstarted!

item.name: Scrabble Junior
item.comment: Ali got this from Grammy for Christmas

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment: On loan from the Chrispy Collection. First play was disastrous and discouraging. Second play was encouraging but very close. Wouldn't mind playing more - enough to master it and feel like including a traitor would actually be fun.

item.name: Sleeping Queens
item.comment: It's a kid's game, get that. It's cute, but not that interesting.

item.name: Sleeping Queens: 10th Anniversary Edition
item.comment: Ali loves this game of course

item.name: Song of Blades and Heroes: Revised Edition
item.comment: Got the PDF and printed copy from the publisher's web site.

item.name: Space Hulk
item.comment: Scored a well-worn copy off of eBay! I almost literally can't get enough of this game. My mind is retroactively blown by this game. I love the Warhammer 40k universe, and this is a really cool skirmish game set in that universe. Feels ripe for expansion.

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel – The Card Game
item.comment: Great solo game or with a couple others. Nicely challenging cooperative game.

item.name: Star Eagles
item.comment: Did a kickstarter to get a physical copy of the rule book and some token things. Had fun drawing up some ships and scenery on cardboard and playing on a regular old wooden table while on vacation with the kids.

item.name: Star Wars: Jabba's Palace – A Love Letter Game
item.comment: Bought from Game Nerdz, excited to try it with the kids since they like regular Love Letter so much. It looks like this one has simplified a few of the rules, which is great so my kids won't have to remember and recognize specific situations.

item.name: Struggle for Catan
item.comment: Interesting little card game translation of Catan. The best thing about it is that it ends pretty quickly, and the second-best thing is that you don't roll any dice. Also, there's no arguing and sheep. Doesn't play very well with two, but three or four is somewhat interesting. The University is clearly the best card though.

item.name: Sushi Go Party!
item.comment: Adds nice variety over the base game, though I don't need extra setup

item.name: Sushi Go!
item.comment: Very much enjoy the "7 Wonders Light" aspect, especially that you can just shuffle the deck and go. Minimal accounting and simple rules make this a favorite for teaching to new players.

item.name: The Table Is Lava
item.comment: Bought from Game Nerdz, essentially to fill up my cart

item.name: Tannhäuser
item.comment: Have had a lot of fun each time I've played it. Very cool theme, very cool maps (supported by the innovative path system), and fun combat. Games usually go down to the wire and rarely involve a stalemate or foregone conclusion.

item.name: Terraforming Mars
item.comment: Very well designed game, lots of interesting decisions and things to think about, and the theme is awesome. The mechanics do a good job of describing the theme too.

item.name: Terraforming Mars: Ares Expedition
item.comment: Doesn't quite live up to my hopes for a cards-only, super-streamlined version of Terraforming Mars. Was actually a little disappointed after our first play but I'm warming back up to it. I don't like the boards, so I've been working on some variant rules and materials to use cards instead of the boards. I would love to be able to play a super quick, minimal setup game of TM, similar to how my wife and I enjoyed so many games of Race for the Galaxy.

item.name: Thunderstone
item.comment: Was pretty hot when it first came out - mainly as a change of pace from Dominion and with a cool Dungeon theme. Has definitely fallen out of favor now though.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: Europe
item.comment: I like Europe better than the U.S. one because of the extra variety

item.name: Ticket to Ride: First Journey (U.S.)
item.comment: Ali got it for Christmas from the Reicherts. I like Ticket to Ride but I really like a smaller faster version. This is the one I'll actually play.

item.name: Tobago
item.comment: Highly entertaining - makes you use your brain, but has plenty of action and excitement too. Has had great staying power, even when playing with the same people multiple times. The variety in the terrain makes a big difference. I really like the choices inherent in the treasure-drafting mechanic.

item.name: Vampire: The Eternal Struggle
item.comment:
Such a well designed game, and it scales well to large numbers! I wish I could get anyone to play with me.
Attempted to get into it when it came out (thought it was the next Magic), but didn't really understand it. Andrew and I had a renaissance in 2007 and played it a bunch but didn't manage to convince anyone else of its worth. Too bad because this is an excellent design.

item.name: The Walking Dead Board Game
item.comment: Pretty lame. We played it a couple times and didn't really enjoy it. It pretty quickly and reliably descends into a no-win situation for the humans. Thematic, but not fun.

item.name: War of the Ring: Second Edition
Warhammer 40,000 (Sixth Edition)
item.comment: I really like the universe and the models and all the hobby activities that go with Warhammer 40k, but I just can't enjoy the actual game of it. The preparation takes too much time with all the nitty-gritty of the army list-making, the ceremony for getting a game going is excessive, and the actual turns are a grind. There is way too high a barrier to fun. I'll admit I haven't played a ton, or with a very wide pool of opponents, but I do think I've played enough to understand that I'm not going to like it in the long run. I really need a simplified, streamlined ruleset to want to play.

item.name: Warhammer 40,000: Dark Vengeance
item.comment: Bought the box set to get the awesome minis at a good price, plus I wanted to read the rulebooks. Making progress painting the minis and comprehending the rules.

item.name: Warhammer Quest: The Adventure Card Game
item.comment: Matt, BDub, and I have played through almost all of this. It's hard, but doesn't feel like it punishes you for losing, which is nice. It gives you a little bump and encourages you to come back for more. It does feel a little like Space Hulk: Death Angel, but with more choices and more interesting interactions.

item.name: Zeus on the Loose
item.comment: Played it a couple times, but there's not a lot there. Arithmetic and the occasional reflex spasm don't make for that much entertainment.
